comment.text: Working as expected.
A bug report seems to be here: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2242454

Plasma crash workaround from KDE Bugzilla: https://bugs.kde.org/show_bug.cgi?id=475266

same behavior as seen by @unakittyyy : plasmashell (wayland) crashes  when launching firefox from the task manager; launching via Bash and Application Launcher seems to work
Same as others - crashes Plasma when launching from the Task Manager in the panel. No crash when opening from the Application Launcher.
Breaks Firefox in Plasma: see https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/FEDORA-2023-bbb8d72c6f

That was probably caused by @stransky 's recent fiddling around with the .desktop file, probably specifically https://src.fedoraproject.org/rpms/firefox/c/85de885472621621af497b204a2f45f7122e8a23?branch=rawhide .

I would strongly recommend you use the workaround suggested by @kjoonlee, do *not* downgrade Firefox. This version is a critical security update.

This update seem to caused a small issue for F38 Plasma users, in the start menu (Application Launcher) there are now 3 Firefox entries:
- Firefox                         (The only entry that will launch Firefox)
- Firefox on Wayland   (Will not launch Firefox)
- Firefox on X11            (Will not launch Firefox)

If you have a pinned shortcut to Firefox on your desktop or in the Task Manager, Firefox will not launch anymore, you have to remove the old pinned shortcut, then make a new one from the Firefox entry in the start menu (Application Launcher).

https://discussion.fedoraproject.org/t/firefox-app-on-desktop-not-opening/91945
It works flawlessly
Working.
Same as @nucleo on amdgpu (RX 7900XTX) at least whole plasma crashes on attempt to launch Firefox, downgrading to previous version fixes it
Plasma desktop crashes when firefox started from quick launch on panel

bugs.title: CVE-2023-5129 firefox: libwebp: out-of-bounds write with a specially crafted WebP lossless file [fedora-all]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2023-5129 firefox: libwebp: out-of-bounds write with a specially crafted WebP lossless file [fedora-all]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2023-5129 libwebp: out-of-bounds write with a specially crafted WebP lossless file

long_desc.thetext:
With a specially crafted WebP lossless file, libwebp may write data out of bounds to the heap.

The ReadHuffmanCodes() function allocates the HuffmanCode buffer with a size that comes from an array of precomputed sizes: kTableSize. The color_cache_bits value defines which size to use.

The kTableSize array only takes into account sizes for 8-bit first-level table lookups but not second-level table lookups. libwebp allows codes that are up to 15-bit (MAX_ALLOWED_CODE_LENGTH). When BuildHuffmanTable() attempts to fill the second-level tables it may write data out-of-bounds. The OOB write to the undersized array happens in ReplicateValue.

https://chromium.googlesource.com/webm/libwebp/+/902bc9190331343b2017211debcec8d2ab87e17a
https://chromium.googlesource.com/webm/libwebp/+/2af26267cdfcb63a88e5c74a85927a12d6ca1d76

Created chromium tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: epel-all [bug 2241119]
Affects: fedora-all [bug 2241120]

Disclaimer: Community trackers are created by Red Hat Product Security team on a best effort basis. Package maintainers are required to ascertain if the flaw indeed affects their package, before starting the update process.

Use the following template to for the 'fedpkg update' request to submit an
update for this issue as it contains the top-level parent bug(s) as well as
this tracking bug.  This will ensure that all associated bugs get updated
when new packages are pushed to stable.

=====

# bugfix, security, enhancement, newpackage (required)
type=security

# low, medium, high, urgent (required)
severity=high

# testing, stable
request=testing

# Bug numbers: 1234,9876
bugs=2240759,2241122

# Description of your update
notes=Security fix for [PUT CVEs HERE]

# Enable request automation based on the stable/unstable karma thresholds
autokarma=True
stable_karma=3
unstable_karma=-3

# Automatically close bugs when this marked as stable
close_bugs=True

# Suggest that users restart after update
suggest_reboot=False

======

bugs.title: Update Firefox in Fedora 39 Final to fix CVE-2023-5169, CVE-2023-5171, CVE-2023-5217

bugzilla.short_desc: Update Firefox in Fedora 39 Final to fix CVE-2023-5169, CVE-2023-5171, CVE-2023-5217

long_desc.thetext:
Fedora 39 Final blocker tracker bug: https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/BugZappers/HouseKeeping/Trackers

To propose a bug as blocking the Fedora 39 Final release, mark it as blocking this bug, or use the webapp: https://qa.fedoraproject.org/blockerbugs/propose_bug . It will be reviewed according to https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/QA:SOP_blocker_bug_process . If you can, please specify the release criterion that the bug violates. See https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Fedora_Release_Criteria for details on the release criteria.

If the bug is not serious enough to block release but you believe it merits being fixed during a milestone freeze (see https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Milestone_freezes ), you can propose it as a 'freeze exception' instead. To do this, mark it as blocking the bug F39FinalFreezeException . See https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/QA:SOP_freeze_exception_bug_process for the freeze exception process.
Fedora 39 was released. Bug closed per https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/BugZappers/HouseKeeping/Trackers

https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/118.0.1/releasenotes/

It contains a security fix.

Reproducible: Always
A build for F39 is still pending. This should be done before the release for sure, given 118.0.1 was a security update.

In general, you don't need to report to the Firefox maintainer that a new Firefox release exists. You can assume they are aware of this. Builds can take a while to appear because building Firefox isn't trivial and takes quite a long time.

Per https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2023-5169 and https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2023-5171, at least two of the CVEs fixed in 118.0 were "important" on the RH scale, and per https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2023-5217 , the one fixed in 118.0.1 is also "important". That does appear to constitute a violation of Final criterion "The release must contain no known security bugs of 'important' or higher impact according to the Red Hat severity classification scale which cannot be satisfactorily resolved by a package update (e.g. issues during installation)."
+3 in https://pagure.io/fedora-qa/blocker-review/issue/1370 , marking accepted.

Looks like x86_64 build for F39 failed again in koji. Interestingly, that worked fine in copr from the same source:

https://copr.fedorainfracloud.org/coprs/bojan/FF/build/6488602/

Weird...
Looks like ld got killed by signal 9 at 162:33:52. Out of memory or something?

Yes. There's some discussion at https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2241690 . It depends to some extent on what builder the job gets assigned to.

I tried to apply a mitigation suggested by Kalev Lember on devel@ , but didn't notice it was inside a conditional that's not currently active, so it didn't work. I've tweaked that and sent new F38/F39 builds. Let's hope these work :(
FEDORA-2023-bbb8d72c6f has been submitted as an update to Fedora 39. https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/FEDORA-2023-bbb8d72c6f

FEDORA-2023-bbb8d72c6f has been pushed to the Fedora 39 testing repository.
Soon you'll be able to install the update with the following command:
`sudo dnf upgrade --enablerepo=updates-testing --refresh --advisory=FEDORA-2023-bbb8d72c6f`
You can provide feedback for this update here: https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/FEDORA-2023-bbb8d72c6f

See also https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/QA:Updates_Testing for more information on how to test updates.

FEDORA-2023-bbb8d72c6f has been pushed to the Fedora 39 stable repository.
If problem still persists, please make note of it in this bug report.
Security fixes in 119.0 are not as dire, but lining up the existing build in bodhi would still be nice to have for the release of F39. :-)
